My Teaching

  We are all learners, and we are all still learning.

Building inclusive teaching environments means respecting that each individual may have different learning styles and starting points.

Teaching can be understood as facilitating a continuous active learning process.

This WI+RE Learning Narrative articulates my firsthand experience as a volunteer at a rural school in Tianshangping (天上平), located in Hubei Province (湖北), China. I was invited to be part of a special team of teachers and school administrators from the Wuhan Foreign Languages School (WFLS), a K-12 academy in central China.

  Learners can be teachers, and teachers can be learners.

Instruction can be a two-way street.

"By teaching you are taught." (Translated from the Japanese film, 日日是好日: Every Day Is a Good Day by Tatsushi Omori). This phrase embodies my view of teaching. The teachers who left the deepest impression on me have always exhibited an interest in learning from the ones they taught. A mutual investment in education and lifelong learning can go a very long way.

The film also advises us that: "Some things are quickly understood, and some things take time. The things easily understood need only be gone through once. But those other things, you come to understand only with time, little by little." Having the patience to work with learners at all stages can nurture understanding that continues to grow far beyond the classroom.

  Teaching Aide for UCLA Global Classroom Program at Jinling High School (金陵中学) | Nanjing, China.

FALL 2019

19th Century American History (Hist XL 19B) | Professor Eric Altice

This course will examine United States history from approximately 1890 to 1990. Major themes include industrialization and it's effects (urbanization, migration, etc), the emergence of the United States as a world power, the development of the Federal Government, Civil Rights, and political party alignment.

Sociology 1 (Soc XL 1) | Professor Justin Gelzhiser

Sociology is the systematic study of society. It is a broad field that covers a wide range of areas of human social life. Additionally, sociology analyzes social life on a wide variety of levels, from interactions between two individuals, to the structure of society as a whole, and even to the interactions between societies on a global scale.

The course will begin with a general introduction to sociology, including several major perspectives and research methods. From there, we will be looking at the interaction between individuals and society, some of the major institutions that shape society, and the power structures that impact social life.
